snippet: Employees sometimes book out of company policy because the preferred hotel or airline is inconvenient.
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column observes employees on business travel sometimes book out of company policy because the preferred hotel or airline is inconvenient; points out his column has long annoyed travel managers by supporting better convenience and comfort for business travelers, even if they do have to go rogue. Drawing (M)t
lead_paragraph: PSST. Want to buy an airplane seat with a tiny bit more legroom so your knees don't knock your chin on that four-hour flight? How about a hotel that's part of a chain where you have a ton of loyalty points and they treat you like family, rather than one across town that your company wants you to use? If you said yes, you may be a candidate for going rogue. That's the term some managers use to describe business travelers who book out of policy. In other words, these travelers do not follow the rules that have been carefully negotiated with suppliers on which airlines, hotels and other travel services to use.

headline.main: Bending Company Policy On Business Travel
